content: The "Agricultural Trade Reform Act of 1999" may be cited as the short title. The definition of domestic industry is provided in the Act. The "Agricultural Trade Reform Act of 1999" defines domestic industry as the producers of like or directly competitive articles or perishable agricultural products in a specific geographic area of the United States. The "Agricultural Trade Reform Act of 1999" defines domestic industry as producers of like or directly competitive articles in a specific geographic area of the United States, whose production constitutes a significant proportion of the total domestic production. The Act allows the commission to make determinations regarding domestic producers. The "Agricultural Trade Reform Act of 1999" defines domestic industry as producers of like or directly competitive perishable agricultural products, citrus products, or potato products in a specific geographic area of the United States, whose production constitutes a significant portion of the domestic industry and primarily serves the market in that area. If there are substantial imports of a like or directly competitive product in that area, only that portion of the domestic industry is considered. The "Agricultural Trade Reform Act of 1999" defines domestic industry as producers of perishable agricultural products, citrus products, or potato products in a specific geographic area of the United States, constituting a significant portion of the industry. The Act further clarifies that a significant portion of the domestic industry includes production in the same growing season. SEC. 3. PROVISIONAL RELIEF. The Trade Act of 1974 is amended to allow provisional relief for imports of perishable agricultural, citrus, or potato products that have been monitored by the Commission for at least 90 days. This relief can be requested by a petition or by the President, Trade Representative, or relevant committees. The Trade Act of 1974 allows provisional relief for imports of perishable agricultural, citrus, or potato products to prevent serious injury to the domestic industry. The Commission must make a determination within 21 days of the request based on available information regarding increased imports causing harm to the domestic industry. The Trade Act of 1974 allows provisional relief for imports of perishable agricultural, citrus, or potato products to prevent serious injury to the domestic industry. The Commission may waive the 90-day period in considering petitions or requests related to potential harm caused by increased imports. The Commission may waive the 90-day monitoring requirement for imports causing serious harm to the domestic industry if there is evidence of significant increases in production or capacity in the exporting country. The Commission can waive the 90-day monitoring requirement for imports causing harm to the domestic industry if there is evidence of production or capacity increases in the exporting country. Amendments are made to specific sections of the Act. Amendments are made to specific sections of the Act, including defining "potato product" as any potato product, including processed ones.
